name: Shrimp Salad with Sour Cream and Dill
ingredients: 1200 g small shrimp; 2 red onions; 2 cups sour cream; 1 bunch dill; 4 tbsp oil; lemon juice; salt; pepper

name: Sauerfleisch from Pork Neck
ingredients: 1 kg boneless pork neck; 1 bottle spirit vinegar; 0.25 bottle white balsamic vinegar; 1 bottle water; 1 onion; 2–3 cloves; 2 juniper berries; 1 bay leaf; 100 g sugar; crushed black or mixed pepper; 2–3 sachets gelatin; salt
preparation: Slice the pork thinly and rub well with salt, then let rest briefly. Bring vinegar, water, onion, spices, and sugar to a boil and adjust the balance of sour and sweet. Add the meat and simmer gently for 1.5–2 hours until tender. Remove the meat, optionally strain the cooking liquid, then dissolve the gelatin according to package instructions and stir it into the hot liquid. Arrange the meat in a single layer in a dish, pour the liquid over it, let cool, and refrigerate until fully set.

name: Mixed Salad with Kieler Sprotten
ingredients: 1 head iceberg lettuce; 4 small cucumbers; 4 medium tomatoes; 12 medium mushrooms; 2 medium yellow beets; 32 Kieler sprats; 4 tbsp light balsamic vinegar; 4 tbsp olive oil; 2 tsp honey; salt; pepper
preparation: Tear the iceberg lettuce into bite-sized pieces, dice the cucumbers, cut the tomatoes into wedges, and slice the mushrooms and yellow beets thinly. Arrange all ingredients on plates. Whisk balsamic vinegar, olive oil, honey, salt, and pepper into a vinaigrette and drizzle over the salad, then place the sprats on top.

name: Potato Soup with Bacon
ingredients: 200 g streaky bacon; 2.67 onions; 133.33 g carrots; 66.67 g celeriac; 800 g potatoes; 1.33 liters meat broth; 1.33 tsp dried marjoram; 2.67 tbsp chopped parsley; salt; pepper; nutmeg
preparation: Peel and dice the onions and potatoes, and cut the carrots, celeriac, and bacon into small cubes. Fry the bacon cubes, add the onions and sauté until translucent. Add the vegetables and potatoes, sauté briefly while stirring, then pour in the meat broth and bring to a boil. Season with marjoram, nutmeg, salt, and pepper. Cover and cook for 30 minutes. Serve sprinkled with parsley.

name: Caesar Salad with Smoked Fish
ingredients: 2 romaine lettuces; 400 g smoked fish (e.g., salmon or mackerel); 8 small slices of crusty bread or croutons; 80 g Parmesan cheese, shaved; 4 tbsp olive oil; 2 tbsp lemon juice; 2 tsp Dijon mustard; 2 cloves garlic, minced; 4 tbsp mayonnaise; salt; pepper
preparation: Wash and chop the romaine lettuce into bite-sized pieces. Flake the smoked fish into small pieces. For the dressing, whisk together olive oil, lemon juice, mustard, garlic, mayonnaise, salt, and pepper. Toss the lettuce with the dressing, then arrange on plates, top with smoked fish, croutons, and shaved Parmesan.

name: Holsteiner Rübensuppe
ingredients: 1 kg beets; 2 medium potatoes; 1 large carrot; 1 onion; 1 liter vegetable or meat broth; 2 tbsp butter; 1 tsp sugar; salt; pepper; 2 tbsp cream
preparation: Peel and dice the beets, potatoes, carrot, and onion. In a pot, melt butter and sauté the onion until translucent. Add the beets, potatoes, carrot, sugar, and broth, bring to a boil, then simmer until vegetables are tender. Season with salt and pepper, blend until smooth, and stir in cream if desired. Serve hot as an appetizer.

name: Matjessalat Hausfrauen Art
ingredients: 300 g matjes fillets; 2 large apples; 2 large onions; 250 ml sour cream; salt; pepper; a pinch of sugar; a little mustard; 2 tbsp fresh chopped dill
preparation: Cut the matjes fillets into about 1 cm pieces and place in a bowl. Dice the apples and onions and add to the matjes. Stir in the sour cream and season with salt, pepper, mustard, and sugar. Finally, fold in the chopped dill and serve.

name: Authentic Eel Soup
ingredients: 1 ham bone (preferably Holsteiner Katenschinken); 3 liters water; 250 g shelled peas (or frozen green peas); 250 g parsnips, diced; 2 leeks, thinly sliced; 0.5 cup finely chopped herbs (thyme, marjoram, tarragon, dill, parsley, chervil); 0.5 celeriac, finely diced; 200 g dried prunes; 125 g dried apple rings; 500 g firm pears, peeled, quartered, cored; salt; freshly ground pepper; 1 pinch nutmeg; 2 tbsp spirit vinegar; 1 tbsp sugar; 1 tbsp butter; 2 tbsp flour; 800 g fresh eel (or 400 g eel fillets)
preparation: This recipe requires a lot of preparation. Boil the ham bone in 3 liters of water, then simmer partially covered for 1 hour. Meanwhile, soak the prunes and apple rings in hot water. Add peas, parsnips, leeks, and celeriac to the simmering broth, reduce heat, and cook for 30 minutes. Remove the bone, scrape any remaining meat back into the soup. Add soaked prunes and apple rings with their soaking water. Mix butter and flour to thicken the soup, cook for 3 minutes, then season with vinegar, sugar, nutmeg, salt, and pepper. Prepare the eel by filleting and cutting into 1 cm pieces, or use pre-filleted eel. Add the eel and chopped herbs to the soup, simmer gently for 15 minutes. Serve with poached or boiled pears on the side; optional: salt-water cooked flour dumplings and chopped sorrel as garnish.

name: Tomato Mozzarella Skewers
ingredients: 500 g cherry tomatoes; 250 g mini mozzarella balls; 1 bunch fresh basil; 3 tsp pesto alla Genovese; 3 tbsp raspberry vinegar or white wine vinegar; 6 tbsp extra virgin olive oil; salt; freshly ground black pepper
preparation: Prepare a marinade by mixing pesto, vinegar, olive oil, salt, and pepper. Drain the mozzarella balls and let them marinate for a short time. Wash the tomatoes and basil. Thread onto toothpicks in the following order: one cherry tomato, one basil leaf, one marinated mozzarella ball, another basil leaf, and a second cherry tomato. Arrange the skewers on a serving plate and drizzle with the remaining marinade.

name: Pesto Bread
ingredients: 600 g flour; 300 ml water; 1 packet dry yeast or 1/2 cube fresh yeast; 0.5 tsp sugar; 2 tsp salt; 50 ml olive oil; 1 jar green pesto
preparation: Prepare a yeast dough using all ingredients except the pesto. Cover and let rise in a warm place for about 30 minutes. Divide the dough into three equal portions and roll each into a round circle. Place the first dough circle on a baking tray lined with parchment paper and spread generously with pesto. Place the second circle on top and spread with pesto again, then cover with the third circle. Mark 16 segments, leaving a small circle in the center, and cut along the lines. Twist each pair of adjacent segments in opposite directions. Let rest for another 10–15 minutes. Bake at 190–200 °C using top and bottom heat for about 20 minutes. Serve by pulling apart the baked sections.

name: Provençal Vegetable Quiche with Goat Cheese
ingredients: 2 packs puff pastry; 2 eggplants; 2 zucchinis; 2 red bell peppers; 2 onions, finely chopped; oil for frying; 6 eggs; 300 ml cream or milk; salt; freshly ground black pepper; 2 handfuls mountain cheese (such as Gruyère or Appenzeller), grated; 300 g goat cheese or feta cheese
preparation: Dice the eggplants, zucchinis, and bell peppers. Finely chop the onions, sauté them in oil until translucent, and allow to cool slightly. Line a tart pan with the puff pastry. Add the onions and vegetables to the pan and lightly season with salt and pepper. Whisk the eggs with the cream, fold in the grated mountain cheese, and season with salt and pepper. Pour the egg mixture over the vegetables. Crumble the goat cheese into small pieces and distribute evenly over the quiche. Bake in a preheated oven at 200 °C  using top and bottom heat until the goat cheese is lightly browned or the pastry edges are golden.

name: Potage Crécy: French Carrot Soup with Ginger
ingredients: 1.5 onions, chopped; 1200 g carrots, peeled and diced; 300 g potatoes, peeled and diced; 3 tbsp butter; 1.5 liters vegetable stock (organic or instant); 3 tbsp flat-leaf parsley, finely chopped; salt; freshly ground black pepper; 1.5 tbsp blossom honey; 1.5 pinches ground ginger; 1.5 tbsp heavy cream, sour cream, or crème fraîche (optional)
preparation: Melt the butter in a large pot and sauté the vegetables over medium heat for several minutes. Pour in the vegetable stock and bring to a boil. Add the parsley, season with honey, salt, pepper, and ginger, then simmer gently for about 20 minutes. Before serving, purée the soup until smooth and, if desired, stir in a small amount of cream, sour cream, or crème fraîche.

name: Scotch Eggs
ingredients: 8 eggs, hard-boiled; 500 g sausage meat; 2 small onions, finely grated; 4 tbsp breadcrumbs; 2 eggs, separated; 2 tbsp fresh parsley, finely chopped; salt; freshly ground black pepper; ground nutmeg; 200 g breadcrumbs; vegetable oil for deep-frying
preparation: Peel the hard-boiled eggs. In a bowl, thoroughly mix the sausage meat, grated onions, 2 tablespoons of breadcrumbs, egg yolks, and parsley. Season generously with salt, pepper, and nutmeg. Divide the mixture into four equal portions. With wet hands, flatten each portion until large enough to completely encase one egg. Wrap the meat mixture around the eggs and press firmly to seal. Lightly whisk the egg whites, brush them over the coated eggs, then roll the eggs in breadcrumbs. Heat oil in a heavy pot and deep-fry the eggs for about 8 minutes until golden brown and crispy. Remove and drain on paper towels before serving.

name: Classic English Soup
ingredients: 1 kg cherry tomatoes, red and yellow; 4 large beefsteak tomatoes; 1 red onion; 1 small chili pepper; 4 garlic cloves; fresh basil leaves, to taste; olive oil, to taste; balsamic vinegar, to taste; salt; freshly ground black pepper; crème fraîche; bread
preparation: Place the washed cherry tomatoes in an ovenproof dish. Roughly chop the beefsteak tomatoes and add them. Finely chop the chili pepper, press the garlic, and distribute both over the tomatoes. Drizzle with olive oil. Roast in a preheated oven at 180 °C  for about 20 minutes. Meanwhile, dice the red onion and sauté it in olive oil, then deglaze with balsamic vinegar. Combine the roasted tomatoes with the balsamic onions and a handful of basil leaves, then blend until smooth. Season with salt and pepper. Serve with a dollop of crème fraîche, fresh basil leaves, and bread.

name: Swedish Zucchini and Potato Soup with Wild Salmon and Dill
ingredients: 700 g floury potatoes; 1 zucchini; 3 tbsp butter; 1 liter vegetable stock; 10 g fresh dill; 100 ml cream; 100 g wild salmon; salt; freshly ground black pepper; sugar
preparation: Wash, peel, and roughly dice the potatoes. Wash, peel, and roughly dice the zucchini. Melt the butter in a pot over medium to high heat until foaming. Add the potatoes and zucchini and sauté, stirring, for about 3 minutes. Pour in the vegetable stock and bring to a boil. Cover and simmer over medium heat for about 15 minutes, stirring occasionally. After about 10 minutes, purée the soup to the desired consistency. Wash and dry the dill, reserving one sprig for garnish. Finely chop the dill tips and stir them into the soup along with the cream. Season with salt, pepper, and a pinch of sugar. Cut the salmon into strips about 1 cm wide. Serve the soup in deep bowls, distribute the salmon evenly on top, garnish with dill, and serve immediately.

name: Swedish Eggs with Peas, Cream Cheese, and Caviar
ingredients: 4 eggs; 1 handful green peas; 1 tbsp fresh dill, finely chopped; 1 tbsp fresh chives, finely chopped; 3 tbsp cream cheese; salt; freshly ground black pepper; 1 jar red caviar; finely grated lemon zest
preparation: Boil the peas for about 3 minutes, drain, and rinse under cold water. Boil the eggs for 8 minutes, then peel and halve them. Remove the egg yolks and mix them with the herbs, cream cheese, and cooked peas until well combined. Season with a little salt and plenty of freshly ground black pepper. Pipe the mixture back into the egg whites. Top each egg half with a teaspoon of red caviar. Garnish with dill or chives and a little grated lemon zest. Serve well chilled.

name: Rosó? (Rossu) – Polish Chicken Broth
ingredients: 150 g chicken meat; 2 carrots; 0.25 celery root; 0.5 leek; 0.5 bunch fresh parsley; salt, to taste; freshly ground black pepper, to taste; Maggi seasoning, to taste; water, as needed
preparation: The chicken meat can come from a whole soup chicken, chicken legs, wings, or a combination of these; the exact quantity is flexible. Traditionally, chicken hearts and gizzards are also used and add excellent flavor, though they are optional. Place the unskinned chicken meat into a large pot and cover with more water than the final amount of soup desired, as some liquid will evaporate during cooking. Cook the meat on its own for at least 20 minutes; if using gizzards, simmer for 45–60 minutes, as they take longer to become tender. Chicken hearts cook in roughly the same time as the meat. While the meat is cooking, peel and halve the carrots and celery root. Clean the leek thoroughly, remove the roots, and cut it in half. Once the meat has cooked for the required time, add the vegetables to the pot and simmer everything together for another 30 minutes. Strain the broth into a second pot using a sieve. Remove the skin and bones from the meat and cut it into small pieces; chop the gizzards as well, while the hearts may be left whole. Dice the carrots and celery root and return them, along with the meat, to the broth. Discard the leek. Season the soup with salt, Maggi seasoning, and freshly ground black pepper. Finely chop the parsley and add it directly to the serving bowls just before serving.

name: Pierogi Ruskie – Polish Dumplings with Potato and Cheese Filling
ingredients: 500 g flour; 1 egg; 1 tbsp oil; 230 ml lukewarm water; 1 level tsp salt; 1 kg waxy potatoes; 500 g cottage cheese; 2 medium onions; salt; freshly ground black pepper
preparation: Prepare the dough by kneading the flour, egg, oil, salt, and lukewarm water into a smooth dough. Roll the dough out thinly. For the filling, cook the potatoes in salted water until tender. While still warm, mash the potatoes and mix with the cottage cheese until smooth. Finely chop the onions and sauté them briefly in a pan until lightly browned, then fold them into the potato mixture. Season with salt and pepper. Cut out round shapes from the rolled dough using a glass and place a small amount of filling in the center of each round. Be careful not to overfill, as the filling may leak during cooking. Fold the dough over and press the edges firmly together, sealing with a fork. Knead together the remaining dough, roll it out again, and continue cutting and filling until all the dough is used; this should yield about 50 pierogi. Cook the pierogi in salted boiling water until they float to the surface, then continue cooking for another 2–3 minutes. Drain well. Serve about 10 pierogi per person, topped with sautéed onions in oil. Sour cream may be served on the side. Any leftover filling can be used to make additional dough or frozen. The pierogi can be prepared in advance and frozen in portions; cook directly from frozen in boiling water when needed.
